ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The course had two live lectures and a synchronous discussion section. But the lectures did also allow for student participation which is why I labeled it as a seminar, because the Professor would spend about half the time putting the readings in context and then we would discuss the readings.
Very small lecture so basically functioned like a seminar but still had virtual discussion section

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this class explored broad themes of history, plus different approaches to studying it (historiography, cultural history, religious history, political theory, economic history). The class did a good job laying a foundation for broad themes in French/European history, such as the Protestant Reformation and the rise of absolutism. Extensive readings of primary sources also allowed the class to study the causes/impacts/reality of these trends.
I learned so much about the Religious Wars, the transition from Renaissance monarchy, state centralization, the Fronde, and the true legacy of Louis XIV, etc.
I learned about early modern France

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professors lectures were engaging, right balance between discussions and lecture, primary readings were really interesting, film screenings added another dimension to the readings 
Weaknesses: we didnt always discuss every reading, so I feel like some of them couldve been cut so we could spend more time on the really important ones

I liked that the short assignments allowed us to be creative or tackle unusual prompts. I also appreciated having the option of either taking a final exam or writing a research paper. I think the reading load should have been lighter considering how dense many of the texts were and that we were expected to read everything by the first meeting of each week.
Lots of work but Professor Sahlin is an incredibly dedicated Professor excited by the topic

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom always makes things worse, but I think the Professor and the class did the best they could in light of the circumstances.
The course was taught well during COVID

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes-I dont know if/when this course will be offered again, but I would really recommend it, but with two caveats. I did not know a lot about France or French history going in, but I was interested in history and European history in particular. Without some type of broad interest going in, you might not like this class. Second, for a lecture class, this courses workload was a bit on the heavy side. About 150 pages of reading per week, a discussion section, two 6 page papers and a final research paper/exam, so if youre not interested in the subject matter the work might seem even greater than it is. That being said, I found the workload manageable and the course fascinating. You get to study Louis XIV, slavery in the New World, Protestant virtue, and other interesting topics.
I would recommend this course to anyone with a genuine interest in the early modern period or the religious history of France. If political theory is not your thing, it will get dry at times.
It was a great course. Professor Sahlins is a tremendous professor
I would not. I think the subject matter, and the manner in which the subject matter was presented was not conducive to an effective course.
